title: Impurity (New Model Army album)
text:
Impurity is a <a href="studio%20album">studio album</a> by <a href="United%20Kingdom">British</a> <a href="rock%20music">rock</a> band <a href="New%20Model%20Army%20%28band%29">New Model Army</a>, released in 1990.
It was the first album without <a href="Bass%20guitar">bass</a>ist <a href="Moose%20Harris">Jason Harris</a>, who had been replaced by Peter Nice (better known as "Nelson"). It was the band's last studio album with <a href="EMI">EMI</a>.
The album sees the band venturing further into the musical territory which they began exploring on their previous album, "<a href="Thunder%20and%20Consolation">Thunder and Consolation</a>" (1989). <a href="Violin">Violin</a>ist Ed Alleyne-Johnson was again a collaborator. It also contained the guitar work of Adrian Portas.
The album reached #23 on the <a href="UK%20Albums%20Chart">UK albums chart</a> in October 1990.
Critical reception.
"<a href="Trouser%20Press">Trouser Press</a>" wrote that the album "exemplifies a fervent, trend- bucking band that has remained true to its original goals."
Singles.
The singles released from the album were "Get Me Out" (September 1990), "Purity" (October 1990) and "Space" (June 1991).
Versions.
The <a href="LP%20album">LP</a> contained 11 tracks, the <a href="Compact%20Disc">CD</a> version included the bonus track "Marrakesh".
The German gatefold-version of the LP had a slightly different cover-artwork. The band logo is printed in light-grey instead of the other version's red logo.
The album was <a href="remaster">remaster</a>ed and <a href="reissue">reissue</a>d in 2005 with a bonus disc containing rarities, <a href="A-side%20and%20B-side">B-sides</a> and live tracks.
